stomach or more properly, of the central cavity - <s>They<\s> It consists 
in its upper or attached part of nothing more than the two 
"foundation membranes" and here they are smooth but at their 
lower or free edge they become much plaited acquire a deeper 
colour and exhibit the characteristic generative elements 
Short tentacles similar to those of Rhizostoma ([paragraph].31) <s>be<\s> are 
scattered over the inner surface of each process (fig. 21) 
[paragraph].43 In the <u>ovarium<\u> the two membranes develope between these  
immense multitudes of ova with a dark granulous yolk 
and clear geminal vesicle. The ova are attached to 
the outer surface of the inner membrane: the outer membrane 
passing quite freely over them (fig. 24) 
[paragraph].44 The <u>Testis<\u> is similarly composed of two membranes, <s>the<\s> 
<s>outer of which is dark<\s> with an intervening space. The 
inner membrane is produced into a vast number of thick 
pyriform sacs which <s>[text?]<\s> lie between the two 
membranes with their blind ends towards  the inner surface 
of the outer membrane; internally, they open each by a distinct 
aperture on the free surface of the inner membrane - the sacs 
are about    in their longest diameter (fig. 22) 
[paragraph].45 The contents of the sacs are spermatozoa and cells in every 
stage of development towards spermatozoa - these stages 
are. 1. Spherical cells 1/1600<sup>th<\sup> of an inch in diameter filled with 
smaller nucleated cells (23a) 2. Cells exactly resembling these 
included cells but free and about 1/5000<sup>th<\sup> of an inch in diameter (b) 
3. Similar cells occasionally united into masses with long
